citation.article-title: Three new species of the genus Actinobispora of the family Pseudonocardiaceae, Actinobispora alaniniphila sp. nov., Actinobispora aurantiaca sp. nov. and Actinobispora xinjiangensis sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Actinobispora alaniniphila sp. nov.
Actinobispora alaniniphila (a. la. ni . ni'phi. la. Gr . adj. philus loving; N.L. fem. adj. alaniniphila alanine-loving)
Cells are Gram-positive, non-acid-fast and aerobic.
The vegetative and aerial hyphae are branched but not fragmented.
Spores are borne in longitudinal pairs on vegetative hyphae and in longitudinal pairs or singly on aerial hyphae and are not motile.
Orange-yellowish vegetative hyphae.
Aerial mycelium is sparse and pink-white.
Neither diffusible pigment nor melanin is produced.
Cells utilize D-fructose, L-rhamnose, D-xylose, D-mannitol, alanine, L-histidine and proline, but not adonitol, cellobiose, raffinose or inulin.
Acid is not produced from these carbon sources.
Cellulose, urea and starch are not degraded.
Pectinase is produced.
Nitrate is reduced.
The strain has weak antifungal activity against Aspergillus niger.
No growth at 45 Â°C.
The cell wall contains meso-diaminopimelic as the diamino acid.
The whole-cell hydrolysate contains galactose and arabinose.
The strain lacks mycolic acid but contains PC, PE, GluNu, PG and PME.
The major menaquinones are MK-9(H2) and MK-7(H2).
The type strain is strain Y-16303T (= CCTCC AA97001T), which was isolated from a soil sample collected at Xichou, Yunnan, China.
